name: atacseq-accessibility-profiling
title: ATAC-seq Chromatin Accessibility Profiling
description: Map genome-wide chromatin accessibility using ATAC-seq. Identifies open chromatin regions, TF footprints, and regulatory elements accessible for transcription.
content:
ATAC-seq Chromatin Accessibility

ATAC-seq (Assay for Transposase-Accessible Chromatin using sequencing) maps open chromatin regions across the genome. The Tn5 transposase cuts and tags accessible DNA, revealing where chromatin is open for regulatory factors to bind.

What is ATAC-seq?

The Technique:

  1. Cells/Nuclei: Start with 50K-500K cells or nuclei
  2. Tn5 Transposase: Inserts sequencing adapters into accessible DNA
  3. Fragmentation + Tagging: Simultaneously cuts and tags DNA
  4. PCR Amplification: Enrich library
  5. Sequencing: Paired-end reads show accessible regions
  6. Analysis: Map reads to identify open chromatin peaks

Why ATAC-seq?

  • Fast & Simple: No antibodies needed (unlike ChIP-seq)
  • Low Input: Works with 500-50K cells
  • Genome-Wide: All open chromatin, not single target
  • Regulatory Map: Promoters, enhancers, insulators
  • TF Footprints: Infer TF binding without ChIP
  • Cell-Type Specific: Different chromatin states per cell type
  • Nucleosome Positioning: Fragment size reveals nucleosome locations

ATAC-seq vs Other Methods

FeatureATAC-seqDNase-seqChIP-seq
Cell Input500-50K1-10M1-10M
Time~3 hours~2 days~2-3 days
Antibodies❌ No❌ No✅ Yes (expensive)
ResolutionBase-pairBase-pair100-500bp
ReadoutAll open chromatinAll open chromatinSingle target
Nucleosomes✅ Yes❌ Limited❌ No

What ATAC-seq Reveals

Regulatory Elements:

  • Active Promoters: Open chromatin at TSS
  • Distal Enhancers: Accessible regulatory regions
  • Insulators: CTCF binding sites (open chromatin)
  • Silencers: Repressive elements

Transcription Factor Footprints:

  • TFs protect DNA from Tn5 cutting → leave "footprints"
  • Infer which TFs are bound without antibodies
  • Computationally predict active TFs per cell type

Nucleosome Positioning:

  • Fragment sizes: <100bp (nucleosome-free), ~200bp (mono-nuc), ~400bp (di-nuc)
  • Nucleosome-free regions (NFR): At active enhancers/promoters
  • Phased nucleosomes: Positioned arrays at regulatory elements

Pipeline Analysis

  1. Quality Control: FastQC checks read quality
  2. Trimming: Remove adapters (especially Tn5 adapters)
  3. Alignment: BWA/Bowtie2/STAR maps paired-end reads
  4. Filtering: Remove duplicates, mitochondrial reads, blacklisted regions
  5. Peak Calling: MACS2 identifies accessible regions
  6. Fragment Size Analysis: Nucleosome positioning from insert sizes
  7. TF Footprinting: TOBIAS or HINT-ATAC predicts TF binding
  8. Differential Accessibility: Compare conditions (DiffBind/DESeq2)
  9. Motif Enrichment: HOMER finds enriched TF motifs in peaks

QC Metrics

  • TSS Enrichment: Signal at transcription start sites (should be >7)
  • FRiP Score: Fraction of reads in peaks (should be >0.3)
  • Fragment Size Distribution: Nucleosome-free peak + periodic nucleosomal peaks
  • Library Complexity: NRF, PBC1, PBC2 metrics
  • Mitochondrial %: Should be <20% (high % indicates dead cells)

Scientific Questions

  • Cell Identity: What regulatory landscape defines this cell type?
  • Activation States: How does chromatin change upon stimulus?
  • Development: Which enhancers open during differentiation?
  • Disease: Aberrant chromatin accessibility in cancer
  • TF Activity: Which TFs are active without doing 100 ChIP-seq experiments?
  • Epigenetic Drugs: Do HDAC inhibitors open chromatin?

Applications

  • Cancer: Aberrant enhancer activation, oncogenic TF activity
  • Immunology: Immune cell differentiation, T cell activation
  • Neuroscience: Neuronal vs glial chromatin landscapes
  • Stem Cells: Pluripotency enhancers, lineage priming
  • Development: Temporal chromatin remodeling during embryogenesis
  • Aging: Age-related chromatin changes
  • Drug Discovery: Epigenetic drug effects on chromatin

Input Requirements

CSV samplesheet with columns:

  • sample: Sample name
  • fastq_1: Path to R1 FASTQ
  • fastq_2: Path to R2 FASTQ
  • replicate: Biological replicate number

Key Outputs

  • Peak Calls: BED files with accessible regions
  • BigWig Tracks: Genome browser visualization
  • Fragment Size Distribution: Nucleosome positioning
  • TF Footprints: Predicted TF binding sites
  • Differential Peaks: Condition-specific accessibility changes
  • Motif Enrichment: TF motifs in accessible regions
  • QC Report: MultiQC with TSS enrichment, FRiP, etc.
  • Consensus Peaks: Reproducible peaks across replicates

Perfect for: Chromatin accessibility • Regulatory elements • TF footprints • Cell identity • Development • Disease epigenetics
